entry.title: January 2014 - Big Data Processing and JavaScript Testing
entry.content:
The January meet up is on Wednesday, January 15th, hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. The talks start at 6:00. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

MRJob – Hadoop made easy.

Sudarshan Gaikaiwari

Big data - you have terabytes of data that you want to crunch through but you don’t want to setup your own hadoop clusters or write Java code to do this. MRJob to the rescue. MRJob is python framework over Hadoop streaming that allows you to write your big data processing programs in any language of your choice. It also supports amazon’s EMR (Elastic Map Reduce) APIs and frees you from the burden of maintaining your own hadoop cluster.

Sudarshan (@sudarshan) works as a software developer at Yelp. His interests are in search, compilers and big data. He loves emacs and free software, and tries to use open source software as much as possible.

Jasmine: JavaScript Testing the BDD Way

Brian Cooksey

Jasmine is a testing framework for JavaScript apps that embraces the Behavior Driven Development (BDD) style of testing. We’ll take a quick tour of the history and methodology behind BDD, then dive in to some of the powerful features that Jasmine offers. Much of the talk will be based around live code examples.

Brian Cooksey (@brian_cooksey / bcooksey on github) is a CoMo native and Mizzou grad. He does web app development in Python and JavaScript for Zapier, with a little bit of security and dev ops sprinkled in. When the power light on the laptop dims, he’s likely spending time with his wife and kids. He also finds time for soccer, gaming, and brewing beer.

Sponsors

This month’s food is sponsored by Yelp. Thanks!

entry.title: DevCOMO November 20th: AngularJS and Go
entry.content:
The November meet up is on Wednesday, November 20th, hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. The talks start at 6:00. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

Angular JS

David Frahm

AngularJS is a modular and highly testable JavaScript MVC framework from Google. This talk will give an overview of the framework, and dissect a small app so you can get a real-world view. Come see why AngularJS is a great option for first-class frontend development.

David Frahm (@davidfrahm) is a Product Developer (frontend dev and UX) at CARFAX where he creates mobile and web apps in an Agile/XP environment. In his spare time, he also creates his own products and is energized by coworking with awesome people.

Go

Ryanne Dolan

*Go* is the answer to the age-old question: what happens when you let the creators of C, Unix, Plan 9, Inferno, UTF-8, sam, etc run loose at the Googleplex? You get a compiled, statically typed, statically linked language that _feels_ like a dynamic scripting language. As the name implies, everything about Go is _fast_ – including development time. In this talk, I’ll introduce Go from a web development perspective, focusing on ways that Go can replace everything in your current stack.

Ryanne Dolan is a CS instructor and PhD student at Mizzou.

Sponsors

This month’s food from Italian Village is sponsored by Veterans United Home Loans. Thanks!

entry.title: October 2013 - Working from home and modern PHP
entry.content:
The October meet up is on Wednesday, October 16th, hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. The talks start at 6:00. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

How to succeed at working from home

Greg Aker

Four years ago, I left my cushy corner-cube job to work from home. My boss gave it six months. I couldn’t let him be right, so I set some rules for myself and got to work. You too can be happy and productive working at home. Welcome, grasshopper.

By day, Greg Aker (@gaker) works as Chief Code Thrasher at nGen Works building awesome things in Django. He also slings the terminal as a systems administrator at EngineHosting.

Modern PHP

Jerel Unruh

PHP is a language that almost every web developer has used at some point. However unless you have used PHP within the last year you probably haven’t observed the recent changes to the language’s ecosystem. This talk touches on package management, features in PHP 5.3 and newer, and covers a very elegant framework named Laravel.

Jerel Unruh is a contractor who creates applications for the modern web using Python, PHP, JavaScript, and Linux. He is the happiest when writing software for himself that will make no money.

entry.title: September 18th, 2013: Repeatable Software Deployments With Docker
entry.content:
The September meet up is on Wednesday, September 18th, hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. The talks start at 6:00. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

Repeatable Software Deployments with Docker

James Carr

Imagine being able to take your application, all of its system level depenencies and being able to package it all up and give it to someone and say “Here, run this.” Linux Containers help provide this kind of capability but are very difficult to use and understand. Docker makes it very easy to build, ship and run containers to allow for 100% repeatable deployments.

James Carr is a DevOps Engineer at Zapier and spends his time automating infrastructure provisioning with puppet and occasionally hacks on product development in Django and node.js.

This month’s food is sponsored by Zapier.

entry.title: August 21st, 2013 - Raspberry Pi with Python, and JavaScript Interpreters
entry.content:
The August meet up is on Wednesday, August 21st, hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. The talks start at 6:00. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

Raspberry Pi, Python, and Planetary Automation.

Doug Royal

Our computers are smart. Our power outlets are dumb. Weâ€™ll fix that by using a Raspberry Pi, some cheap hardware, and a few lines of Python.
Doug Royal @dougroyal is a software developer at CARFAX by day, and an electronic hobbyist at night. In his spare time he writes and illustrates FallaciousLogic.net.

JavaRubyScript

Tyler Pickett

A brief exploration into writing a JS interpreter with Ruby.
A Springfield, MO native, Tyler Pickett (@tpickett66, https://github.com/tpickett66) came to CoMO for engineering school and never really left.

entry.title: July 17th, 2013 - Application monitoring and Objective C
entry.content:
The July meet up is on Wednesday, July 17th, hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. The talks start at 6:00. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

Using New Relic For Server Monitoring

James Carr

Setting up an extensive monitoring solution for your application can be time consuming and difficult. Tonight I’ll demonstrate using New Relic to keep tabs on server performance, monitor and debug production applications and show how to use the recently launched platform to monitor all of the services in your stack. I’ll also give a brief demonstration of how to record deployments to track application performance changes that result from new code roll outs.
James Carr is a DevOps Engineer at Zapier and spends his time automating infrastructure provisioning with puppet and occasionally hacks on product development in Django and node.js.

Modern Objective C

Bryan Pratte and Brett Koonce

We will look at some modern Objective-C techniques (ARC, Blocks) and some traditional methods that many people do not use (Categories, Extensions). Also, we will take a peek at iOS 7 and Xcode 5.

Sponsors

New Relic provides deep application monitoring for your web and mobile apps without the time-consuming configuration.

entry.title: June 19th, 2013 - SEO friendly single page web applications
entry.content:
The June meet up is on Wednesday, June 19th, hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. The talks start at 6:00. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

SEO friendly single page web applications

Nathan Stitt

Discussing different approaches to creating a single page web application that can also be spidered by search engines. Techniques covered will be Rails 4’s TurboLinks, my liquid_assets gem, and a phantomjs driver as used in Meteor.
Nathan Stitt (github profile) is a local software developer who operates a single person software consultancy. He primarily writes in Ruby, Javascript, and Objective-C, but has dabbled in most others. He’s currently hacking on his uber app, ledger buddy.

entry.title: May 15th, 2013
entry.content:
The May meet up is on Wednesday, May 15th, hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. The talks start at 6:00. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

Web Scraping with Python and Scrapy — for Great Justice!

Ceili Cornelison

Web scraping can save infinite hours of valuable human-time. I will be giving an overview of Scrapy, an open source web crawling and scraping framework built for Python, and demonstrating how you, too, can script time-consuming but unavoidable web tasks out of your daily workflow.
Ceili Cornelison (@cornelisonc) spends her days developing web applications for Delta Systems Group in Columbia, MO. She works primarily in PHP/HTML and CSS/JavaScript, and spends her nights contemplating open source development, spanish reds, emerging web technologies and the future of all mankind.

Sponsors

PyroCMS is an MVC PHP Content Management System built to be easy to use, theme and develop with. It is free and open-source and is used by individuals and organizations of all sizes around the world. :-)

entry.title: April 17th, 2013 - Cloud Automation and Grails
entry.content:
The April meet up is on Wednesday, April 17th, hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. The talks start at 6:00. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

Cloud Automation Like a Boss

James Carr

There’s a plethora of tools out there for automating your infrastructure. This talk will focus on a set of tools I’ve found immensely useful: fabric, boto, and vagrant. I’ll demonstrate how to use fabric and boto to automate infrastructure tasks on EC2 and how to use fabric in conjunction with vagrant to provision servers both locally and in the cloud.
James Carr is a DevOps Engineer at Zapier and spends his time automating infrastructure provisioning with puppet and occasionally hacks on product development in Django and node.js.

Grails

Shane Davenport

Brief overview of Groovy and Grails and what some of the advantagesare over just using Java. Explanation of MVC (Model View Controller) and how it is used in a grails application.
Shane Davenport @shanewdavenport works at CARFAX were he uses Test Driven Development in an Agile work enviroment to deliver software solutions to customers. Shane started programing with Visual Basic and then moved into .NETin 2003 and now Java and Groovy. He has always had an interest inseeing how technology makes our lives easier, more fulfilling, and creating software solutions that deliver an excellent experience to the end user.

Sponsors

To Be Announced

entry.title: March 20th, 2013 - Phono, WebRTC, and Rails security
entry.content:
The March meet up is on Wednesday, March 20th, hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. Show up around 5:30pm for networking/food. The talks start at 6. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

Comms-enabling your apps with Phono and WebRTC

Brian Pitts

Phono is an open-source library that turns any web browser or mobile app into a phone or chat client. I’ll provide an overview of different communications protocols, including the emerging WebRTC standard, and show you how easy it is to use them via Phono.

Brian Pitts works remotely as a systems engineer for Voxeo Labs, where he follows the teachings of @DEVOPS_BORAT.”

Rails Security

Ian graves

Reviewing the Latest Rails Vulnerability, CVE-2013-0333 and Friends

The Rails framework was recently revealed to have a critical vulnerability that allowed for remote code execution on the server. Many commonly used iterations of Rails have been shown to have security issues because of these findings. This talk will step through what makes Rails vulnerable and how an exploit would work. It’s fair to expect a demo that includes a vulnerable Rails distribution, Metasploit, and cursing by Ian when it doesn’t work perfectly.

Bio:

Ian Graves is a PhD student in the Center for High Assurance Computing at the University of Missouri. His research focus centers around languages and security implications therein. Haskell is his jam, but Ruby’s okay too.

entry.title: February 20th, 2013 - Heroku and Vagrant
entry.content:
February’s meetup is on Wednesday, February 20th. It will be hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute. Come by around 5:30pm – the talks start at 6. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

Introduction To Heroku

Clint Shryock

Heroku is a Platform as a Service (PaaS): running your apps in the clouds with ease and a lot of purple. We’ll see how to create apps on Heroku and scale them, and get a brief intro into how things work.
Clint Shryock is a born Columbia native who currently telecommutes as a software engineer for Heroku, Inc, in San Francisco. He works in Ruby with Rails, Sinatra, and does some CLI tooling when he can. He has been writing web apps professionally since 2004. At night he gallivants between Ruby, Cocoa, and Riak hacking.

Being a Vagrant for Fun and Profit

James Carr

Virtualization is a must have these days for local development, whether you are wanting to test your chef or puppet manifests out in a local throw away environment or create a re-distributable virtual environment for others on your team to use.
Vagrant is a tool that allows you to create and configure lightweight, reproducible, and portable development environments with an extremely easy to use interface written in ruby. I’ll detail how to use vagrant to bootstrap new instances, use puppet for provisioning resources within a new virtual instance, and even how to use vagrant to boot up many small virtual machines to test clustering out.
James Carr is a DevOps Engineer at Zapier and spends his time automating infrastructure provisioning with puppet and occasionally hacks on product development in Django and node.js.

Sponsors

Heroku

Thanks this month to our sponsor Heroku for picking up the food. Come by and learn about how it could make your deployments easier! We may even have some other goodies and door prizes.

entry.title: Notice Anything Different?
entry.content:
Our Group Name Has Changed To dev/como

After some discussion on our mailing list, we have decided to rename ComoRichWeb to dev/como! Or, more formally, DevCoMO.

The primary reason is that we have a variety of developers in town, and not all of them are focused on web development. We want to promote the group to any local developers, not exclusively to web devs.

New Website

We are also ditching our old posterous site and moving forward with our new, shiny Octopress site here at http://devcomo.com.

Our Plan Going Forward

We are going to be working hard to get the word out and make necessary changes. We think it will be worth it as we try to broaden our appeal to developers in the mid Missouri area in the future.

Here are some of the things we are planning on doing in the near future:

  • Working on a new logo. Jerel did a great job with the ComoRichWeb logo, which actually still kind of fits, but we will probably be looking to make some kind of change to show the new name.
  • Updating our social presences, on Twitter, Google+, Github, and our mailing list.
  • Updating the web site to show more relevant news and information about our speakers and sponsors.

How You Can Help

  • Help get the word about the group out with other developers and designers in town.
  • Come to our meetups (like tonight’s) and help grow our community. We are always open to suggestions on ways that we can make the group better.
  • Our new website could use some help and ideas as we build it out further. Come talk to me at the meetup or send a message if you are interested in this.

entry.title: January 2013 - Refactoring and Local Startup BottlCap
entry.content:
ComoRichWeb January 16, 2013

Bring in the new year by learning about some awesome technology and entrepeneurship in Columbia.

January’s meetup is on Wednesday, January 16th! It will be hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute (directions). Come by around 5:30pm - the talks start at 6. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby.

Local Startups - BottlCap - Social Jukebox App

Ryanne Dolan

Continuing our series of showcasing Missouri startups and the technology they are being powered with, we will learn about BottlCap (@BottlCap).

BottlCap is developing a location-aware social jukebox app. We’ll present the tech that makes it possible. FeedGraph is the backend for the apps. The best way to describe the project is a read-write version of Facebook’s Graph API. The API is generic enough to support everything we need across all the apps. It uses a highly scalable real-time architecture built on Amazon’s EC2, S3, et al.

Ryanne is a CS PhD student and instructor. BottlCap is Brad Siegler (CEO), Tony Patrick, and John Schultz.

(Not) Refactoring Considered Harmful

Tyler Pickett

Refactoring is an essential part of the modern TTD development process. By taking advantage of the protection afforded by automated testing we can improve the readability and maintainability of our code while maintaining its functionality.

Tyler Pickett is a Missouri native who came to Columbia to attend MU in the Mechanical Engineering Department in 2003. After completing a BS and the course work for a MS he joined Research to Practice developing a Rails app. You can find him at @tpickett66 orhttps://github.com/tpickett66.

See you on January 16th!

entry.title: December 2012: Zapier Developer Platform and Book'd
entry.content:
ComoRichWeb December 12th Meetup

You won’t want to miss our great speakers this month at ComoRichWeb! They are founders of two different companies started in Columbia, and will be speaking about technology and product development behind their ventures.

December’s meetup is on Wednesday, December 12th! It will be hosted at Reynolds Journalism Institute (directions). Come by around 5:30pm - the talks start at 6. We meet in the glass room right in the main lobby. Come hungry if you want, as we will definitely be getting some good food, compliments of Zapier.

Intro to Zapier Developer Platform

Mike Knoop

Zapier is a web app to connect other online services together. We support over 120 services. More than half were added by third parties via our Developer Platform. I will demo the Platform and add a brand new app live on stage.

Mike Knoop is a co-founder at Zapier and recent Mechanical Engineering grad from Mizzou. Originally from Wildwood, Missouri, he is working full time at Y-Combinator alum, Zapier, hacking on Backbone, Coffeescript, and Sass. In past lives he has been seen as a Facebook Forum Moderator, writer for InsideFacebook.com, and Z80 assembly programmer for the TI-83/84 calculator series.

Lesson Learned from Building Book’d

Jamie Stephens

Book’d allows small businesses to list their services and availability and begin taking online bookings from customers in minutes. It is built with Ruby on Rails. Jamie will share some of lessons he has learned over the last few years about product development and running Book’d.

Jamie Stephens is a software engineer who spent the last dozen or so years helping other businesses get their ventures off the ground before deciding to venture out onto his own with Book’d. He spends most of his time working with Ruby on Rails, but also tries to design things when no one is looking.

Sponsors

Zapier will be sponsoring food for this meetup, and Mizzou Advantage is sponsoring the venue. Be sure to thank them for supporting our group!

Zapier

Zapier makes it easy to connect hundreds of the most popular web services, automate boring tasks and get stuff done. It was started in Columbia, MO at Startup Weekend. Check them out at zapier.com or say hi to @zapier.

Mizzou Advantage

Mizzou Advantage fosters interdisciplinary collaboration among faculty, staff, students and external partners to address and solve real-world needs and problems at the University of Missouri.

See you in December!

entry.title: November 2012: Stripe Capture the Flag and Ruby On Rails
entry.content:
November’s meetup is on Wednesday, November 14th! It will be hosted at RJI (directions). Come by around 5:30pm - the talks start at 6.


Note: This month’s meetup is at the Reynolds Journalism Institute, in the same room we had our workshop night a few months back.  The room is visible from the main lobby, with large glass windows.  Walk in the front door, and keep going straight until you can’t anymore.

Stripe Capture The Flag

By: Ian Graves - University of Missouri, Center for High Assurance Computing

About the talk: 

The Stripe Capture the Flag 2.0 contest was a web-based security contest put on by Stripe, the new and awesome payment processor.  The contest focused on important yet-frequently-overlooked security issues with web applications including SQL injections, XSS.

The CTF consisted of nine challenges for participants to work through. I plan on giving an overview of the contest as a whole and giving a live demo of a selection of challenges, time permitting.

About Ian

Ian Graves is a professional student PhD student at the University of Missouri studying security vulnerabilities and their relation to compilation techniques.  He spends most of his day writing Haskell and dealing with systems-level coding, but has been known to moonlight with Ruby and Rails.

Intro To Ruby On Rails

By: Joshua Smith - The Add Sheet!

About the talk: 

Ruby on Rails is an open source web framework for Ruby that allows for rapid development of web applications

About Joshua

Joshua Smith is the lead developer at The Add Sheet. He manages the full-stack for the addsheet.com Rails app. After hours, he dabbles in Backbone.js and iOS programming, usually including their integration with Rails.

 

Hope to see everyone at RJI this month!

entry.title: October 2012: Massively Scaling to Millions of Players: A League of Legends Story
entry.content:
October’s meetup is on Wednesday, October 24th! Here’s the gist: it will be hosted at our usual Museao location (directions). The talk will start around 6:00pm but come by around 5:30pm or so if you want to hang out beforehand.

Come join us on October 24th.  We are having an out of town guest from Riot Games come to present about scaling an online game to millions of users!

Massively Scaling to Millions of Players: A League of Legends Story

By: Scott Delap

In this talk, we will cover the challenges and lessons-learned of scaling and operating the PvP.net Platform that supports millions of League of Legends global players daily.

In addition to covering software architecture and design choices in building PvP.net, we will cover the often-overlooked (in the race to market) aspects of monitoring, deployment, analytics, testing and automation.

About Scott

Scott Delap is a scalability architect at Riot Games, Inc. creator of the award winning online MOBA game League of Legends. He focuses on architecture for large scale, fault tolerant application platforms. Scott is also the former lead Java editor for InfoQ.com. In past lives Scott is the author of the popular Desktop Java Live ebook and a seasoned UI developer. Scott is a frequent presenter at conferences such as JavaOne, QCon and No Fluff Just Stuff. He won a Java Rockstar Award for his 2006 JavaOne presentation on Swing Threading.

 

Hope to see everyone at Museao this month!

entry.title: September 2012 - ComoRichWeb Workshop Night!
entry.content:
September 26th, 2012 (that’s a Wednesday)

ComoRichWeb will be hosting a workshop night with a focus on getting local developers together for training / learning about specific topics. We will offer 3 tracks from local professionals, with two sessions each lasting 30-45 minutes, allowing attendees to attend 2.

Workshop Details

entry.title: August 2012: Getting Started with Django and Lightning Talks
entry.content:
August’s meetup is on Wednesday, August 15th! Here’s the plan: it will be hosted at our usual Museao location (directions). Talks start at 6:00pm but come by around 5:30pm or so if you want to hang out beforehand.

Come join us on August 15th.  Based on our member survey, a lot of people are interested in learning more about Python and Django.  Greg Aker is going to stop by and share some tricks in a ‘Getting Started with Django’ session.

Getting started with Django

By: Greg Aker

Django is Python’s “Swiss Army Knife” web development framework. Let’s look at how easy it is to get up and running, be productive and have fun developing complex web applications!

About Greg

By day, Greg Aker (@gaker) works as Chief Code Thrasher at nGen Works building awesome things in Django. He also slings the terminal as a systems administrator at EngineHosting. 

 

Lightning Talks

By: ???

Come by and do a short presentation on anything you are interested on.  Have a new tool or technology that you have been using and want to show off?  Know some cool text editor tricks that you want to share?  Take the stage and present it.  We assume lightning talks will be <= 5 minutes.

Hope to see everyone at Museao this month!

entry.title: July 2012 - Capistrano and Sinatra
entry.content:
July’s meetup is on Wednesday, July 18th! Here’s the deal: it will be hosted at our usual Museao location (directions). Talks start at 6:00pm but come by around 5:30pm or so if you want to hang out beforehand.

Come join us on July 18th as two of the ComoRichWeb organizers share their experience with some great Ruby tools and libraries!

Using Capistrano to Deploy Anything

By: James Carr

Still struggling FTP’ing content out to your servers? rsync have you down? Stop wasting your time and come hear about how you can use Capistrano to deploy anything to any server you have ssh access to with zero downtime, regardless whether your app is written in PHP, Rails, or Node.js. I’ve give an overview of Capistrano, the deployment lifecycle, and demonstrate deploying (and rolling back) changes on a live site. I’ll also briefly touch upon using Jenkins to deploy using capistrano. 

About James

James Carr is a local developer who works works on JVM based projects at Carfax by day and hacks on ruby and node.js projects at night. He’s an active open source contributor and passionate about enabling software development communities.

Sinatra: The Little Not-Framework That Could

By: Clint Shryock

Sinatra is a well known DSL for building websites, web services, and web applications in Ruby. At just around 2,000 lines of code, it’s the smallest, most versatile non-framework out there. In this session I’ll give you a basic intro on working with Sinatra (including a quick intro to Rack), show some useful features, and probably screw up some live coding.

About Clint

Clint Shryock is a Columbia native who currently telecommutes as a software engineer for Cramer Development in Iowa City, IA. He works in Ruby/Rails and PHP and has been writing web apps professionally since 2004. At night he gallivants between Ruby, Cocoa, and Riak hacking.

Hope to see everyone at Museao this month!

entry.title: June 2012 - Startup Q & A and Chrome Developer Tools!
entry.content:
Junes’s meetup is on Wednesday, June 20th! Here’s the deal: it will be hosted at our usual Museao location (directions). Talks start at 6:00pm but come by around 5:30pm or so if you want to hang out beforehand.

DevTools, Part II

By: Brian Grinstead

If you are doing any web development – learning and using the browser based developer tools will make your life easier. Don’t worry if you missed Part I (back in November), we’ll hit the highlights before digging further into script debugging, web design in the browser, and some of the new features available in both Chrome and Chrome nightly.

About Brian

Brian Grinstead (@bgrins) is a web developer who works on open source projects, like his JavaScript Colorpicker (also in WebKit), FileReader.js, javascript-astar, mothereffinganimatedgif, and Instant Sprite. Brian works locally on Foliotek Presentation.

Startup Q & A

By: Brent Beshore and Brant Bukowsky

We’ll have a Q & A session with Brent Beshore and Brant Bukowsky. For those of you who don’t know, Brent and Brant are two major entrepreneurs from the local area and have started several successful area companies. Come on out and bring whatever questions you have on what it takes to get a successful startup off the ground.

About Brent

Brent owns AdVentures, which invests in communications-based companies. These investments range from ad agencies and media properties to a software development firm and a film company. There are currently 13 active investments and AdVentures was recently ranked #28 on the 2011 Inc. 500.

Brent is involved in the national startup scene, serving on the advisory board of Startup Missouri and recently joined Gen Y Capital Partners, a $30 million venture capital tech fund based out of NYC, as a Venture Partner.

Brent is the founder of the League of Innovators, which is a 16,000 sq. ft. co-working space and entrepreneurial incubator and involved in a number of non-profits as a board member including the Heart of Missouri United Way and the Community Foundation of Central Missouri. Brent’s efforts in launching the Joplin, MO Tornado Recovery Facebook page and raising $2 million for the relief efforts garnered him a 2011 VH1 Do Something Award nomination.

About Brant

Brant and his brother started their first company while pursuing education degrees at Mizzou and have gone on to start over a half dozen companies. Their first company, ShowMe Tickets, sold event tickets and was acquired in 2005 by a company that was later acquired by Ticketmaster. LakeRentals.com, an online vacation rental company, started that same year was acquired by The Weather Channel 18 months later. Their current company, Veterans United Home Loans, is a nationwide mortgage bank they started in 2002. It currently employs over 800 people.

The brothers have received the Inc 500 award, for being one of the fastest growing private companies in the US, for 3 separate companies. Brant was selected as a mentor for the Clinton Foundation’s Emerging Entrepreneur program where he mentored small businesses in Harlem, NY. He has been doing online marketing since 1999 and has spoken at national conferences regarding online marketing.

He is passionate supporter of entrepreneurship and lives in Columbia, MO with his wife and 2 boys.

Hope to see everyone at Museao this month!
